In the context of generative artificial intelligence, AI agents (also referred to as compound AI systems) are a class of intelligent agents distinguished by their ability to operate autonomously in complex environments. Agentic AI tools prioritize decision-making over content creation and do not require human prompts or continuous oversight.[29]

They possess several key attributes, including complex goal structures, natural language interfaces, the capacity to act independently of user supervision, and the integration of software tools or planning systems. Their control flow is frequently driven by large language models (LLMs).[30]

Researchers and commentators have noted that AI agents do not have a standard definition.[30][31][32][33]

A common application of AI agents is the automation of tasks—for example, booking travel plans based on a user's prompted request.[34][35] Prominent examples include Devin AI, AutoGPT, and SIMA.[36] Further examples of agents released since 2025 include OpenAI Operator,[37] ChatGPT Deep Research,[38] and Manus.[39] Frameworks for building AI agents include LangChain,[40] as well as tools such as CAMEL,[41][42] Microsoft AutoGen,[43] and OpenAI Swarm.[44]

Companies such as Google, Microsoft and Amazon Web Services have offered platforms for deploying pre-built AI agents.[45]

Proposed protocols for standardizing inter-agent communication include the Agent Protocol (by LangChain), the Model Context Protocol (by Anthropic), AGNTCY,[46] Gibberlink,[47] the Internet of Agents,[48] and Agent2Agent (by Google).[49] Software frameworks for addressing agent reliability include AgentSpec, ToolEmu, GuardAgent, Agentic Evaluations, and predictive models from H2O.ai.[50]

In February 2025, Hugging Face released Open Deep Research, an open source version of OpenAI Deep Research.[51] Hugging Face also released a free web browser agent, similar to OpenAI Operator.[52]

Galileo published on Hugging Face a leadership board for agents, which ranks their performance based on their underlying LLMs.[53]

A non-peer reviewed research survey of 67 agents released by the end of 2024 found that the majority of agents are built by developers based in the United States, built by companies, purposed for coding or computer interaction, have code or documentation, and lack safety policies or evaluations.[54]

A non-peer-reviewed paper by researchers at CSIRO lists software frameworks for monitoring agents as they are being used in production, and proposes a taxonomy of concepts relevant to AgentOps.[55]

The Financial Times compared the autonomy of AI agents to the SAE classification of self-driving cars, comparing most applications to Level 2 or Level 3, with some achieving Level 4 in highly specialized circumstances, and Level 5 being theoretical.[56]

As of April 2025, per the Associated Press, there are few real world applications of AI agents.[57]

A recruiter for the Department of Government Efficiency proposed in April 2025 to use AI agents to automate the work of about 70,000 United States federal government employees, as part of a startup with funding from OpenAI and a partnership agreement with Palantir. This proposal was criticized by experts for its impracticality, if not impossibility, and the lack of corresponding widespread adoption by businesses.[58]

Proponents argue that AI agents can increase personal and economic productivity,[35][59] foster greater innovation,[60] and liberate users from monotonous tasks.[60][61] A Bloomberg opinion piece by Parmy Olson argued that agents are best suited for narrow, repetitive tasks with low risk.[62] Conversely, researchers suggest that agents could be applied to web accessibility for people who have disabilities,[63][64] and researchers at Hugging Face propose that agents could be used for coordinating resources such as during disaster response.[65]

Potential concerns include issues of liability,[35][59][61] an increased risk of cybercrime,[34][59] ethical challenges,[59] as well as problems related to AI safety[59] and AI alignment.[34][61] Other issues involve data privacy.[34][66][67][68][69][70][65] Additional challenges include weakened human oversight,[34][35][59][65][66][67] algorithmic bias,[66][71] and compounding software errors,[34][36] as well as issues related to the explainability of agent decisions,[34][67] security vulnerabilities,[34][35][65][68][71] problems with underemployment,[71] job displacement,[35][71] and the potential for user manipulation,[67][72] misinformation[65] or malinformation.[65] They may also complicate legal frameworks, foster hallucinations, hinder countermeasures against rogue agents, and suffer from the lack of standardized evaluation methods.[61][69] They have also been criticized for being expensive[30][69] and having a negative impact on internet traffic[69] and potentially the environment.[69]

Journalists have described AI agents as part of a push by Big Tech companies to "automate everything".[73] Several CEOs of those companies have stated in early 2025 that they expect AI agents to eventually "join the workforce".[74][75] However, in a non-peer-reviewed study, Carnegie Mellon University researchers tested the behavior of agents in a simulated software company and found that none of the agents could complete a majority of the assigned tasks.[74][76]

Yoshua Bengio warned at the 2025 World Economic Forum that "all of the catastrophic scenarios with AGI or superintelligence happen if we have agents".[70]

In March 2025, Scale AI signed a contract with the United States Department of Defense to work with them, in collaboration with Anduril Industries and Microsoft, to develop and deploy AI agents for the purpose of assisting the military with "operational decision-making."[77] Researchers have expressed concerns that agents and the large language models they are based on could be biased towards aggressive foreign policy decisions.[78][79]

Research-focused agents have the risk of consensus bias and coverage bias due to collecting information available on the public Internet.[80] NY Mag unfavorably compared the user workflow of agent-based web browsers to Amazon Alexa, which was "software talking to software, not humans talking to software pretending to be humans to use software."[81]

Agents have been linked to the Dead Internet Theory due to their ability to both publish and engage with online content.[82]

Agents may get stuck in infinite loops.[37][83]

Zico Kolter noted the possibility of emergent behavior as a result of interactions between agents, and proposed research in game theory to model the risks of these interactions.[84]

Guardrails, defined by Business Insider as "filters, rules, and tools that can be used to identify and remove inaccurate content" have been suggested to help reduce errors.[85]

The concept of agent-based modeling for self-driving cars was discussed as early as 2003.[86]

Hallerbach et al. explored the use of agent-based approaches for developing and validating automated driving systems. Their method involved a digital twin of the vehicle under test and microscopic traffic simulations using independent agents.[87]

Waymo has developed a multi-agent simulation environment, **Carcraft**, to test algorithms for self-driving cars.[88][89] This system simulates interactions between human drivers, pedestrians, and automated vehicles. Artificial agents replicate human behavior using real-world data.

Salesforce's Agentforce is an agentic AI platform that allows for the building of autonomous agents to perform tasks.[90][91]

The Transport Security Administration is also integrating agentic AI into new technologies, including machines to authenticate passenger identities using biometrics and photos, and also for incident response.[92]
